column1: Another ingenious postal device which has just been put on trial is the scheme for registering letters yourself.The first thing to do is to put a ten-cent piece in the slot. The coin opens a small registering window
column2: and reveals a pad on which you write the address of the registered letter
column3: and also an aperture through which the letter is to be dropped. The letter must first have been stamped with a two-cent stamp.After the letter is mailed
column4: the sender pulls a handle until a gong rings and a receipt is then pushed out toward the sender. This receipt is in fact the second half of the order which he himself has written. As soon as the receipt is given the machine locks itself
column5: and nothing will unlock it but a fresh dime in the slot.Worn coins
column6: or those that are not full size and weight
column7: are instantly rejected by the machine.The coin
column9: passes over a very delicate balance
column10: and if it is found to be light or bad when it is weighed
column11: the machine throws it out on the floor in front of the would-be registerer.
